content.text: Once upon a time, when wishes still came true, there lived a sorceress who was very wicked.
She had a beautiful daughter whom she loved dearly, but she also had a stepdaughter whom she hated with all her heart.
One day, the sorceress decided to get rid of her stepdaughter once and for all.
She took the poor girl into the depths of a great forest, where the trees grew so tall and thick that the sun could scarcely pierce through their branches.
There, in the darkest part of the woods, the sorceress had prepared a terrible spell.
She led the stepdaughter to a large iron stove, black as night, with a small door at the front.
The sorceress muttered strange words, and suddenly, the stove began to glow with a fierce, red light.
"Climb inside," she commanded the girl, her voice cold and cruel.
The stepdaughter, trembling with fear, begged and pleaded, but the sorceress would not listen.
With a wave of her hand, she forced the girl into the stove and shut the door behind her.
Then, with another spell, she turned the stove into a small, unremarkable iron pot and hid it deep in the forest, where no one would ever find it.
But the sorceress had not counted on the power of the girl's kindness.
Though she was trapped inside the iron stove, the stepdaughter was not alone.
A small, magical creature—a fairy, perhaps, or a spirit of the forest—had heard her cries and taken pity on her.
The creature whispered to her through the iron walls, "Do not be afraid.
I will help you, but you must be patient.
One day, a prince will come to this forest, and he will set you free."  Years passed, and the stepdaughter waited inside the iron stove, her heart filled with hope.
Meanwhile, far away in a grand kingdom, a young prince was hunting in the very same forest.
He had ridden ahead of his companions, chasing a magnificent stag, when he became lost among the towering trees.
Night fell, and the prince found himself alone in the dark woods, with no sign of his hunting party.
As he wandered, he came upon a small clearing where the moonlight shone down upon a strange sight: an iron stove, standing all alone in the middle of the forest.
The prince approached it curiously and heard a soft voice calling from within. "Who is there?" the voice asked.
The prince, startled but brave, answered, "I am a prince, lost in the woods.
Who are you?"  "I am a maiden," the voice replied, "trapped inside this iron stove by a wicked sorceress.
If you will help me, I will be forever grateful." The prince, moved by the maiden's plight, tried to open the door of the stove, but it was locked tight.
"I cannot open it," he said, "but I will not leave you here.
I will return with help."  The prince hurried back to his kingdom and gathered his most trusted servants.
Together, they returned to the forest with tools and torches, determined to free the maiden.
They worked for hours, trying to break open the iron stove, but it was enchanted and would not yield.
Just as they were about to give up, the prince remembered the maiden's words.
"Perhaps there is another way," he said.
"Let us try speaking to the stove."  The prince knelt before the iron stove and said, "Maiden, if you can hear me, I promise I will not rest until you are free.
Tell me what I must do." To his amazement, the stove began to glow softly, and the door creaked open just a little.
A small, delicate hand reached out, and the prince took it gently.
"You must break the spell," the maiden whispered.
"The sorceress who trapped me here is the only one who can undo it, but she will not do so willingly.
You must find her and make her say the words that will set me free."  The prince knew this would not be easy, for the sorceress was powerful and cunning.
But he was determined to save the maiden, so he set off at once to find the sorceress.
After many days of searching, he came to her castle, hidden deep in the mountains.
The sorceress was not pleased to see him. "What do you want, prince?" she sneered.
"Why have you come to my home?"  "I have come for the maiden trapped in the iron stove," the prince said boldly.
"You put her there, and you must set her free." The sorceress laughed, a cruel and mocking sound.
"And why should I do that?" she asked. "What will you give me in return?"  The prince thought quickly.
"I will give you anything you ask," he said, "if you will only free the maiden." The sorceress's eyes gleamed with greed.
"Very well," she said.
"I will free the maiden, but first, you must bring me the golden apple that grows in the garden of the sun.
Only then will I say the words that break the spell."  The prince knew this was a trick, for the golden apple was guarded by fierce dragons and could not be taken easily.
But he was not afraid.
He set off at once for the garden of the sun, where he battled the dragons and claimed the golden apple.
When he returned to the sorceress, she was forced to keep her word.
She took the apple and muttered the words that broke the spell.
In an instant, the iron stove vanished, and the maiden stood before the prince, more beautiful than he had ever imagined.
The prince was overjoyed, and he took the maiden's hand. "Come with me," he said.
"You will never be trapped again." But the sorceress was furious.
"You may have freed her," she hissed, "but you will never escape me!" She raised her hands to cast a spell, but the maiden was quicker.
She whispered a few words of her own, and the sorceress was turned into a stone, frozen forever in her anger.
The prince and the maiden returned to his kingdom, where they were married in a grand celebration.
The maiden, who had once been trapped in the iron stove, became a beloved princess, and she and the prince lived happily ever after.
And as for the sorceress?
She remained a stone in the mountains, a warning to all who would use magic for cruelty.
And so, my dear child, remember this: kindness and bravery will always find a way, even in the darkest of times.
Now close your eyes and dream of forests and princes, of iron stoves and happy endings.
